bioghist.p: John Burnett Payne was born on Feb. 10, 1919, in University Park, New Mexico but he was educated in the Midwest at Translyvania University and Univ. of Cincinnati during the 1930s. In 1951 Payne moved to Manhattan where he began to teach at Pratt Institute and where he began a thirty year career in writing. In addition to teaching, during the 1960s Payne worked as a reader for several publishers, including Avon Books. During the 1970s Payne published two chapbooks: Tell Me That You Love Me, Con Edison, and Ghosts Scare Tito Rosa. His poetry has appeared in numerous small magazines such as Kauri, Open Places, Gyro, and Premiere. Payne was also a contributor to Current Biography and Yale Quarterly Review.

scopecontent.p: The papers of this little known New York poet include extensive personal correspondence, 1940s-1980s, manuscripts for published and unpublished poems and critical essays, clippings, handbills, photographs, watercolors, pamphlets, and some financial records. The collection also includes reader's reports (written by Payne) of books under consideration for publication by Avon Books, 1980-1984. The extensive correspondence with friends and writers provide insight into the person and the artist. The correspondents include; Helen Barkus, Dennis Barone, Karin Haggar, Roemol Henry, Allen Hoey,Tony Hannon, Shirley Powell, Steven Samet, Elaine Selig, Betty Greaves, and Ken Wallace. The collection also documents Payne's work, especially his unpublished biography of Daniel Fuchs, writings on [Julie Friedhof], and his ongoing relationship with Banjo Press.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
